title: 113_hr4938
content: The Act titled "Guantanamo Bay Detainee Transfer Suspension Act of 2014" temporarily limits the use of funds to transfer or release individuals detained at United States Naval Station, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. The Guantanamo Bay Detainee Transfer Suspension Act of 2014 restricts the use of funds to transfer or release detainees from Guantanamo to foreign entities, with exceptions for court orders. The Guantanamo Bay Detainee Transfer Suspension Act of 2014 prohibits the transfer or release of detainees from Guantanamo to foreign entities, with exceptions for court orders. The Secretary of Defense must notify Congress of any orders issued, and enforcement includes a $10,000 civil penalty for each detainee transferred in violation of the act. The United States Government cannot provide representation or reimburse private counsel for officers or employees in certain actions. A person can bring a civil action for a violation on behalf of the Government, seeking a civil penalty. The action can only be dismissed with consent from the court and the Attorney General. A civil action can be brought by a person on behalf of the Government for a violation, with the complaint and evidence served to the Government. The Government has 30 days to decide to intervene or decline to proceed with the action. If the Government declines to take over the action, the person bringing the action can conduct it. The Government must be served with all pleadings and deposition transcripts at its expense. The person bringing the action is entitled to 50% of the civil penalty imposed on the officer or employee of the United States, along with reasonable expenses awarded by the court. The court may award reasonable expenses, attorneys' fees, and costs to the person bringing a civil action. The courts must expedite the appeal process for dismissed civil actions. The Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Secretary of State and the Director, must submit a report within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Secretary of State and the Director of National Intelligence, must submit a report to Congress detailing the assessments of the risk of 5 detainees transferred to Qatar from Guantanamo Bay reengaging in terrorist activity. The report should include any changes in assessments and reasons for such changes. The report to Congress must include a detailed description of Qatar's past failures to monitor detainees from Guantanamo Bay, an assessment of the likelihood of the 5 detainees returning to terrorism, and the potential impact of their transfer on terrorist groups trying to capture them. The report to Congress must include details on terrorist groups attempting to capture US individuals for concessions. The report should be unclassified but may have a classified annex. Definitions include the appropriate committees of Congress. The term "covered detainee at Guantanamo" refers to non-US citizens or members of the US Armed Forces held at Guantanamo Bay by the Department of Defense. The term "officer or employee of the United States" includes the President and officials of Executive agencies or military departments. The term "officer or employee of the United States" includes the President, officials of Executive agencies, and does not include members of the Armed Forces or employees of the intelligence community. SEC. 3 prohibits the transfer or release of detainees from Guantanamo Bay without the President's written authorization. This applies to detainees like Khalid Sheikh Mohammed who are not US citizens or members of the Armed Forces, held at Guantanamo Bay by the Department of Defense since January 20, 2009. SEC. 4 clarifies that this Act does not override the requirements of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2014 regarding the transfer or release of detainees from Guantanamo Bay.
